questions.text: A 36-year-old man presented with complaints of bluish-black discolouration of sclera and pinna for last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine turns black on standing as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria and results due to excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

It is an autosomal recessive condition due to deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase).

The homogentisic acid is then oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-coloured alkapton bodies, which deposits in soft tissues like cartilage and is called as ochronosis.

Image A - Normal urine
Image B - Alkaptonuria

Related Pearl: Metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Disorder

Enzyme defect

Phenylketonuria

Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Tyrosinosis (Tyrosinemia type I)

Maleyl Acetate isomerase or Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Maple syrup urine disease 

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD)

Alkaptonuria

Homogentisate oxidase

Albinism

Tyrosinase

Homocystinuria type I

Cystathionine synthase

Homocystinuria type II

Defect in methylcobalamin formation

Cystathioninuria

Cystathionase

Tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome

Tyrosine transaminase or Tyrosine aminotransferase

Primary hyperoxaluria

Alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase

Hypervalinemia

Valine transaminase

Isovaleric acidemia

Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase

Histidinemia

Histidase

Hyperprolinemia type I

Proline oxidase

questions.text: Which of the following is used to estimate the visual field?
questions.solution:
• All the options are used to estimate the visual field.
  • Types:
    • Manual perimetry: Confrontation method, Lister’s perimeter, Campimetry (Scotometry), Goldmann’s perimeter
    • Automated perimetry: Octopus Fieldmaster, Humphrey Field Analyzer

The image given below shows Lister's perimeter.

Image: The above image shows the confrontation method for testing the visual field.

questions.text: The police hands over the body of a person who died due to hanging to you for an autopsy. Which of the following incisions is preferred in this case?
questions.solution:
The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression (as in hanging) is the modified Y-shaped incision.

In strangulation, hanging, and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, a modified Y-shaped incision is to be preferred. This incision is used because the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised to give a wide approach to the neck structures.

Given below are types of incisions done for an autopsy:

Y-Shaped Incision: Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side. It runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum in the midline. It then runs downwards as in an I-shaped incision to the symphysis pubis. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy.

Modified Y-shaped incision: An incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from the suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. Indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck. 

I-Shaped Incision: Extends from symphysis mentii to symphysis pubis taking curve towards left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice. It is simple and convenient.

Elongated X-shaped Incision: This is a special incision used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries, which are usually missed where superficial imprints are faint, particularly when present on skin not overlying bone. This is helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death and should be practiced in cases of custodial death.

Inverted Y-shaped incision is used in infants.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch and then run downwards as in the “I” shaped incision.  Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A pregnant woman complained of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks at a period of gestation of 14 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart sound is absent.  USG shows the presence of a snowstorm appearance. What is the management____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and regardless of uterine size, molar evacuation by suction and curettage is usually the preferred treatment. 

With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are imperative.

Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound healing procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The principal behind the wound healing procedure, as shown above, is negative pressure wound therapy.

Applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds and ulcers.

The negative pressure may act by decreasing oedema, by removing interstitial fluid and by increasing blood flow. As a result, bacterial counts decrease and cell proliferation increases, thereby creating a suitable bed for graft or flap cover.

questions.text: Immunization is ____.
questions.solution:
Immunization is a form of primary prevention, through specific protection.

  • Primary prevention is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that disease will ever occur.
  • Population strategy and high risk strategy are used as part of primary prevention.
  • Examples: Immunization, sanitation, and protection of food.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients

Patients

questions.text: Dutcher bodies are seen in_____.
questions.solution:
Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma.

  • Russell bodies: Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig.
  • Mott cells/morula cells: Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of Ig
  • Flame cells: Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections
  • Thesaurocytes: Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae

Image – A binucleate plasma cell with intranuclear Dutcher cells.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): The Arnold's nerve innervates the skin over a small part of the ear and external auditory canal. In patients with chronic cough, scratching or mechanical stimulation of ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough.

Causes of referred otalgia Nerve responsible Site
Temporomandibular joint and dental conditions, parotid infections/tumor, and anterior 2/3rd of tongue Auriculotemporal nerve Tragal area, crus of the helix, and anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal. 
Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, carcinoma base of the tongue or tonsils (oropharynx) The glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's) Medial surface of the tympanic membrane, and middle ear
Carcinoma of the larynx (cough), hypopharynx, epiglottis, vallecula, esophagus, and thyroid Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's/Alderman's nerve) Concha, posterior wall, and floor of the external auditory canal
Cervical spondylitis Great auricular nerve (C2,3) Lateral and medial surfaces of the pinna
Acoustic neuroma Facial nerve (nervus intermedius/nerve of Wrisberg)

Concha, retro auricular groove, and posterosuperior part of the external auditory meatus. Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall known as Hitzelberger's sign, is seen in acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: The following image shows a deformity as a result of a fracture. It is associated with________

choices.text: Anesthesia over tip of little finger

questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the image above is cubitus valgus on the left side. It can affect the ulnar nerve leading to anaesthesia at the tip of the little finger. 

Cubitus valgus is a late complication of non-union of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus.  It can lead to late-onset ulnar palsy also called tardy ulnar nerve palsy. This can cause anesthesia at the tip of the little finger, which is the zone of autonomous supply of ulnar nerve.

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • The optimal time for performing CECT is more than 72 h after the onset of symptoms (In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis).

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gall stone induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the investigation of choice. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

 Balthazar Score

Balthazar Grade

Appearance on CT

CT Grade Points

Grade A

Normal CT

  0 Points
 

Grade B

 Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas  1 Point
 

Grade C

 Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation   2 Points

Grade D

 		 Fluid collection in a single location  3 Points
 

Grade E

 Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas  4 Points
Necrosis Score  

Necrosis Percentage

  

Points

No necrosis

    

0 Points

 
 

0 to 30% necrosis

    

2 Points

 
 

30 to 50% necrosis

  

4 Points

 

 
 

Over 50% necrosis

    6 Points

 

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points.

questions.text: A patient presented with vomiting to medicine OPD. He has a history of eating fried rice. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Food poisoning after eating fried rice is due to Bacillus cereus.

Food poisoning caused by B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8-16 hours 1-5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1-6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8-16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic E.coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E.coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves is a pure sensory nerve?
questions.solution:
The olfactory nerve is a pure sensory nerve. It carries no motor fibers.

  • Olfactory: Sensory
  • Optic: Sensory
  • Oculomotor: Motor
  • Trochlear: Motor
  • Trigeminal: Both 
  • Abducent: Motor
  • Facial: Both
  • Vestibulocochlear: Sensory
  • Glossopharyngeal: Both
  • Vagus: Both
  • Accessory: Motor
  • Hypoglossal: Motor

"Both" stands for a mixed nerve (both motor and sensory).

Mnemonic: Some Say Marry Money But My Brother Says Big Brain Matters More.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a history of fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found in his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient would be infective endocarditis.

Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:

  • Roth spots: These are are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
  • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds are used in PET scan?
questions.solution:
PET involves the use of a radiolabelled bio compound - 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) which is injected intravenously. It is based on the principle that tumour cells have a high metabolic rate. FDG is metabolised to FDG-6-phosphate which cannot be further metabolised by tumour cells, and hence it accumulates and concentrates in tumour cells. This accumulation is detected and quantified.

Applications of PET :-

Oncologic:

  • Detection, staging, drug response
  • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence

 Neurologic:

  • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
  • Localisation of seizure focus in interictal phase
  • Localising eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)

Cardiac: Identification of hibernating myocardium

questions.text:
A 25-year-old infertile male underwent semen analysis. 
Results show: sperm concentration - 16 million/ml: pH- 7.5: volume - 2 mL: no agglutination is seen. 
Morphology shows 60% normal and 60% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
This male with sperm concentration 16 million/mL is considered to be normospermia.

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL.

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Latest WHO standard for semen analysis - 2021:

Semen analysis Normal reference value
Semen volume  >1.5 mL
Sperm concentration 15 million/mL
pH >7.2
Total sperm number  >39 million/ejaculate
Total motility  >40%
Progressive motility  >32%
Vitality  >58% live sperm
Normal forms   >4%
Agglutination Particles <2

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

  • Volume: 1.5 mL
  • PH: 7.2–7.8
  • Viscosity : <3 (scale 0–4)
  • Sperm concentration ≥15 million/mL 
  • Total sperm count: ≥39 million/per ejaculate 
  • Motility: 40% or more with 32% progressive motility
  • Forward progression: >2 (Scale of 0-4)
  • Normal forms: 4% (strict criteria) 
  • Vitality: 58% or more 
  • White blood cells: < 1 million/mL
  • Round cells: 5 million/mL
  • Sperm agglutination: <2 (Scale 0-3)

questions.text: Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: The most common site is axilla
TNF alpha inhibitors like adalimumab can be used in treatment
Obesity and smoking are the 2 main factors associated with it
Surgery cannot be done for this condition.

questions.solution:
The given image shows hidradenitis supurativa or inverse acne. Surgical excision is the best treatment that offers a cure for the patient.

  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease that usually presents after puberty.
  • There are painful, deep‐seated inflamed lesions in the apocrine gland‐bearing areas of the body, most commonly the axillary, inguinal and ano‐genital regions.
  • The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:
    1. Typical lesions, that is deep‐seated, painful nodules: ‘blind boils’ in early lesions; abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars and paired or multiheaded open pseudocomedones in secondary lesions.
    2. Typical topography: axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
    3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions.
  • Obesity and smoking are the two main factors associated with hidradenitis suppurativa.

Treatment includes 

  • Antibiotics like Tetracycline, clindamycin
  • Intralesional corticosteroids
  • Immunosuppresants
  • Acitretin
  • Anti TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the casualty department with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. His attender reported that he had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and had recently started treatment. What is the drug of choice to treat the patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced parkinsonism, for which the drug of choice is benzhexol, also known as trihexiphenidyl. 

Benzhexol is an antimuscarinic agent. Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol acts by restoring the balance of the cholinergics in the striatal interneurons.

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Drug class

Examples 
Typical antipsychotics

Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics Metoclopramide, levosulpiride
Calcium channel blockers Flunarizine, cinnarizine

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida had pre-pregnancy BMI of 30 kg/msq. What is the recommended weight gain during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The recommended weight gain the above case is not more than 7 Kg.

Ideally weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy body mass index (BMI) level.

Category

BMI

Recommended weight gain

Underweight

<18.5

12.5–18 kg

Normal

18.5–24.9

11.5–14 kg

Overweight

25–29.9

7–11.5 kg

Obese

>30

7 kg

Related Pearl: Recommendation for total weight gain during pregnancy by pre-pregnancy BMI

Category (BMI) Total weight gain range [kg(lb)]
Underweight (<18.5) 12.5 - 18 (28-40 lb)
Normal weight (BMI 18.5-24.9) 11.5 - 14 (25-35 lb)
Overweight (BMI 25-29.9) 7 – 11.5 (15-25 lb)
Obese (BMI more than equal to 30) 5 - 9.1 (11-20 lb)

questions.text: Which of the following renal stones is not formed in acidic urine?
questions.solution:
Struvite stone is produced in alkaline urine, especially when urea-splitting proteus organisms are present.

  • Struvite is a triple-phosphate calculus (calcium phosphate often with ammonium magnesium phosphate), grossly smooth in texture, and dirty-white in color.
  • The calculus may enlarge to fill most of the collecting system, forming a stag-horn calculus.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: The image shown below is the technique of insertion of?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of laryngeal mask airway.

Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Classic Laryngeal Mask Airway

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and ventilated patients during anesthesia.

LMA has advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics). This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for the inexperienced provider and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx so that, once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most universally accepted health status indicator?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live.

Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000

It is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is also among the best indicators of state failure.

The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the clinic with a non-specific history of malaise. Mild sensorineural hearing loss had been diagnosed during his early education, although hearing aids were not required. He gives a history of recurrent hematuria and current investigations reveal the same. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Alport syndrome is a cause of recurrent hematuria, which is associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible for Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.

 Other causes of recurrent hematuria

  • Alport syndrome
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Papillary necrosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following people would you not classify as a high risk contact of SARS-CoV2?

choices.text: A family member who lives in the same household as the patient
A doctor who examined the patient with a surgical mask and gloves
A passenger in the same bus as a symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive
A sanitary worker who cleaned the linens of the patient

questions.solution:
A person traveling in the same environment and not having significant exposure to the confirmed case is not classified as a high-risk contact.

A contact of COVID-19 is a person living in the same household or having direct physical contact with the patient/infectious secretions without appropriate PPE or a person who was in a closed environment or at a distance of within 1 meter of a COVID-19 case.

High-risk contacts:

  • Touched body fluids of the patient
  • Had direct contact with the body of the patient during the physical examination without proper PPE
  • Touched or cleaned the linens, clothes, or dishes of the patient
  • Lives in the same household as the patient
  • Comes in close contact (within 1 meter) with the patient without necessary precautions
  • A passenger in close proximity with the symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive

Low-risk contacts:

  • Shared the same space but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.
  • Travelled in the same environment but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of greenish discharge from the nipple for the past 1 month. Personal history is significant for cigarette smoking. On compression of her breast, greenish discharge from multiple ducts was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia. 

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula or nipple retraction.

Related Pearl: Discharges from the nipple

Discharges from the nipple:

Discharge from the surface

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

Discharge from a single duct

  • Blood-stained
    • Intraductal papilloma
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour)
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

Discharge from more than one duct

  • Blood-stained
    • Carcinoma
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent
    • Infection
  • Serous
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

Remember:

  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from single duct is duct papilloma.
  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is duct carcinoma.
  • The most common cause of serous discharge from the breast is fibrocystic disease of breast.

questions.text: Identify the structure 'e'.
questions.solution:
The image depicts MRCP (Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography)

  • Non invasive test
  • Endoscope is not used
  • No contrast medium used (Bile serves as a contrast medium)
  • Heavy T2 weighted image

a - Gall bladder with gall stones

b - Ampulla of Vater

c - Pancreatic duct

d - Duodenum

e - Common bile duct

questions.text: Vasopressin has maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: While conducting a screening camp for coronary heart disease, you encounter the following people. Who among them is at the highest risk for developing this disease?

choices.text: A person who is competitive and ambitious
A person who is calm and relaxed
A person who tends to suppress their emotions
An introverted person with negative affectivity

questions.solution:
A person who is competitive and ambitious is said to have a type A personality. Such people are more prone to develop coronary heart disease (CHD). Personality type is a non-modifiable risk factor for CHD.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality 

Option B: A calm and relaxed person is said to have a type B personality.

Option C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions, especially negative emotions, is said to have a type C personality.

Option D: A person with negative affectivity and social inhibition is said to have a type D personality.

questions.text: A healthy child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. The child comes in with a toy in her hand and readily shares it with the doctor. She is able to say her name. Her mother says she does most of her activities with her right hand now. If she is given a paper and pen, which of the following will she be able to do?
questions.solution:
This child who is able to say her name, shares toys, and has developed handedness is around three years of age and she will be able to copy a circle.

Developmental milestones at the age of three:

Social and Emotional:

These children usually copy adults and friends, engage in cooperative play, show affection for friends and concern for crying friends without prompts, understand the concept of ownership but are able to share toys, show a wide range of emotions, and may get upset with changes in routine easily.

Language and Communication:

Follow instructions with two/three steps, can name most things around them, understand prepositions, use pronouns, name friends and make a simple conversation with two sentences.

Cognitive:

Copy a circle with a crayon, turn book pages one at a time, build towers with six or more blocks, screw and unscrew jars/lids and can do puzzles with four or fewer pieces

Motor:

Climb well, run easily, pedal a tricycle and walk up and down stairs with one foot on each step

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera. His liver function tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzyme levels. Liver biopsy revealed an accumulation of dark melanin like pigment in the hepatocytes. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with dark pigment deposition (image below) in the liver. These features are suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome.

In Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) there is defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin and various compounds like epinephrine metabolites causing the liver to appear black.

Rotor syndrome also has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but there is no pigmentation of the liver. Serum bilirubin levels are not helpful in differentiating between Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) and Rotor's syndrome as both these conditions present with mild elevation of serum bilirubin.

These two conditions can be differentiated as follows:

Test Rotor Syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Oral cholecystography Gall bladder is visualized

Gall bladder not visualised 

Impaired ability to concentrate the contrast material into bile
Total urinary coproporphyrin Elevated

Normal 

Increased excretion of coproporphyrin 1 and decreased excretion of coproporphyrin 3
Bromsulphalein (BSP) clearance test

Delayed clearance of BSP

No reflux

Rise in plasma levels of BSP after 90 minutes of injection

Reflux of BSP from hepatocytes 

Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Related Pearl: Rotor syndrome vs Dubin johnson syndrome

  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Inheritance Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Defect Organic anion transporting polypeptide  defect.(OATP1B1,OATP1B3) Multi drug resistance protein (MRP )2 mutation
Biopsy Normal Black pigmentation
Conjugated bilirubin Elevated Elevated
Kernicterus absent absent

questions.text: What should the minimum duration of symptoms be to diagnose post-traumatic stress disorder?
questions.solution:
The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.
